text:
“Road connectivity a major drawback for north east tourism” Secretary Ministry of Tourism India Published  

Travel And Tour World was in conversation with Vinod Zutshi Secretary, Ministry Of Tourism Government Of India at the International Tourism Mart 2015 Gangtok, Sikkim. Zutshi felt that connectivity is an important aspect of tourism and the government is working on improving connectivity. The country has many unfinished airport projects and there are plans that these would be used by chartered flights bringing foreign tourists to make the airports usable. He also reflected on cruise tourism and the government is working on making better use of cruise tourism by building better infrastructure.
 
He also felt happy with the progress on e-visa. He felt that tourism has increased with the introduction of this facility. Given by the improvement in the flow of visitors the ministry is hoping that this facility would be extended to 150 countries.
 
Eco -tourism is a top priority for India. The Secretary praised Sikkim for bringing an ‘organic revolution’. He also said that there are other parts of India which are practicing eco-tourism and the tradition is set to grow.
 
The secretary revealed that the travel marts will get greater shape to extend to other corners of India. The secretary expressed his concern over the connectivity issue of North East. There are plans of making immediate progress on the connectivity process where these regions will find a better link with the rest of the country.
